header.title: THE TRANSPERSONAL ARCHAEOLOGIST: AN INTERCHANGE OF SCIENCE AND INTUITION (Article from AASC Newsletter, Vol. 3, No. 2, June 1987)

central_thesis: Traditional archaeology, often focused on quantitative and left-brain methods, can be significantly enriched and gain deeper insights by consciously integrating intuitive, right-brain methodologies, experiential meditation, and 'New Age techniques' like dowsing and 'automatic experimental tool making,' particularly when applied at sacred sites, leading to a more efficient, balanced, and harmonious discipline.

structure_content.summary: Highlights the one-sided nature of traditional archaeological training and proposes that integrating intuition and right-brain methods can enhance archaeological research, leading to greater insight.

Presents a fictionalized account of Dr. Hillebrand, an archaeologist who gains precise knowledge of excavation sites and historical information through an intuitive connection and 'affinity' with past inhabitants at sacred ruins, illustrating the potential of transpersonal archaeology.

Describes a practical method where archaeologists replicate prehistoric artifacts (e.g., flintknapping) to 'get into the minds of the prehistoric tool makers,' noting experiences of being guided by an external intelligence or greater knowledge during the process, leading to verifiable conclusions.

Introduces pendulum dowsing as a 'New Age technique' for locating objects or sources of raw materials (like obsidian) within archaeological contexts, with personal anecdotes demonstrating its efficiency in saving time and resources during fieldwork.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Scientific Cycle and New Age Methodologies
structure_content.summary: Argues for integrating New Age methodologies into the scientific cycle, particularly for hypothesis generation, citing that even 'hallucinations' can form verifiable hypotheses. Emphasizes experiential meditation at sacred places as a tool for generating relevant research directions.

Advocates for a paradigm shift in archaeology, balancing quantitative methods with qualitative approaches. Proposes that cultivating 'affinity or communication with past people through meditation trance states and sacred places' alongside empirical observation and scientific methods will create a more efficient, balanced, and harmonious discipline.

key_concepts.definition: An archaeological approach that integrates traditional scientific methods with intuitive, right-brain methodologies, including dowsing, experiential meditation, and 'automatic experimental tool making,' to gain deeper insights into prehistoric cultures and human behavior.

The non-quantitative, non-linear cognitive faculty recognized as a source of 'important and creative ideas, syntheses, and conclusions' in archaeological research, which, when consciously integrated, can enhance understanding and efficiency.

An intuitive 'feel for where excavation or survey units should be placed.' The author suggests that by bringing this intuitive sense into conscious awareness, archaeologists can achieve greater insight and save considerable time.

A practical technique, such as replicating prehistoric chipped stone tools (flintknapping), where the practitioner aims to 'get into the minds of the prehistoric tool makers' and may experience being guided by 'someone with greater knowledge,' leading to unexpected and verifiable results.

A 'New Age technique' applied in archaeology for divination and locating hidden objects, features, or raw material sources (e.g., obsidian deposits) by interpreting the movements of a pendulum over maps or directly at a site.

A practice involving meditation at archaeological sites or other sacred locations to foster affinity with past peoples, generate relevant research directions, and facilitate personal transformation for the archaeologist.

practical_system.description: The article outlines a practical system for 'Transpersonal Archaeology' that consciously integrates both traditional left-brain (scientific, quantitative) and right-brain (intuitive, qualitative) approaches. This system aims to enhance archaeological research by tapping into non-ordinary sources of information and insight, leading to more efficient fieldwork, deeper understanding of past human behavior, and even personal transformation for the researcher.
tools: Pendulum: Used as a dowsing instrument to locate hidden archaeological features, objects, or raw material sources on maps or directly in the field.
Obsidian Sample: Utilized as a sympathetic link during dowsing to locate obsidian sources, enhancing the specificity of the dowsing inquiry.

Tobacco, Ancient Turquoise Beads, White and Red Shell, Obsidian, Feathers, Down, Corn Pollen: Ritual items mentioned in the fictional parable as being used for offerings to establish communication or affinity with the past.
rituals: Experiential Meditation at Sacred Places: Involves sitting at archaeological sites or sacred locations, allowing for spontaneous insights, fostering 'affinity' with past inhabitants, and generating research directions. The author's experience in Carrizo Gorge serves as an example.

Offerings to the Past: As depicted in the 'Parable of Truth,' performing ritual offerings (e.g., tobacco, beads, feathers, corn pollen) at ancient sites can facilitate 'communication' and 'affinity' with the spirits or energies of past peoples.

'Automatic' Experimental Archaeology: Engaging in the replication of prehistoric artifacts (e.g., flintknapping) with an open mind to intuitive guidance, or 'asking for help' from past toolmakers, to achieve insights or technical mastery beyond normal skill.

relevant_quotes.text: Much of what we do and the directions we take in archaeology is guided by intuition.

This judgmental sampling is simply an intuitive feel for where excavation of survey units should be placed. By bringing this intuitive sense into the conscious left brain, much greater insight may be gained and much time may be saved.
My purpose frequently is to 'get into the minds of the prehistoric tool makers' by replicating artifacts produced by the people that lived in the sites I work on.

Recently, while at a site in the Colorado Desert, I was able to produce a point much thinner and better executed than usual and in a style typical of that part of the desert. I felt like I could make no mistakes and was guided by someone with greater knowledge than I.
For most people it takes only a limited amount of effort to become a passable dowser and the uses in the field are virtually unlimited.
Carl Hempel stated that hypotheses can be generated by any number of processes 'even hallucinations' so long as the testing sequence is verifiable when presented with alternatives (1966).
Archaeology for humanity is to help us not forget that we are just as much the past as the present or future---the people of the past can still teach us much that we have forgotten.

critical_analysis.relevance: This article is highly relevant to the Esotericism and Occultism specialty as it explicitly advocates for the integration of 'New Age methodologies,' intuitive practices, and altered states of consciousness (implied by 'affinity' and 'communication with past people through meditation trance states') within a scientific discipline like archaeology. It directly bridges the gap between empirical science and intuitive/esoteric experience, discussing how practices such as dowsing (a form of divinatory magic) and intuitive guidance in craft (akin to channeling or gnosis) can be integrated into practical research. It resonates with themes found in Chaos Magic (experimental approach to gnosis) and Hermeticism (understanding deeper, hidden realities).
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes academic archaeologists open to expanding their methodological toolkit, practitioners of 'New Age techniques' seeking applications in empirical scientific fields, and individuals interested in the philosophical and practical intersection of science, intuition, and consciousness studies.
